document.text: Your correspondents health has been very good since he came to the army although typhoid fever seems to be prevalent here and a large number of men are in the hospital and it is very common to hear of one and some days three ,or four being dead. I understand that W. J . Bryan arrived here last week with his regiment and that he is now en camped at a place celled Panama a few miles from here. Company H . to which yonr correspondent belongs was organized several years ago at Salem, V a., and W. Griffin is now the Captain who apparently is a very nice gentleman and a good officer this company is mostly com posed of Southwest Virginia men, a large number of them being from Roanoke and Radford. I did not find the climate as warm as I ex pected, however the snn is very op pressive at times, this is a level section, no mountains to be seen and it is frequently heard in th camp by the boys that they desire once more to see the mountains. We have splendid teligous s e r v ic e , preaching nearly every night and twice every Sabbath by different preachers and chaplains of the dif ferent regiments encamped. Your correspondent has met several times with Mr. Robt. Johnson of White H all, who is in- the 4th Va., regi ment, I have not met with any other soldier from Buckingham or Appomattox since I have been here. Some days news of encouragement comes into the camp that peace may soon be brought about, and then again different reports are made which add another tone to the news. So I do not think that anyone really knows when the war will come to an end.

document.text: Your best chance of finding a farm with cattle or calves is to go to northern V irginia a n d o r to th at area commonly referred to as  west of the Blue Ridge. A survey, conducted by J. D. Johnson, agricultural economist at VPI Experim ent Station in coopera tion with the Virginia Division of M arkets and the Virginia Crop Re porting Service, showed th a t nearly one-half of the farm s w ith cattle inventories in 1951 were located in those two areas northern and w est of the Blue Ridge. Further, about 70 per cent of the states cattle pop ulation was on farm s in those areas Inform ation on livestock inventor ies, m arketing practices, production practices, and pasture productnin and managem ent, was gathered on 7,000 farm s in 47i counties during the survey. The findings are not surprising. Johnson says, when you rem em ber that much of the land can only be used for pasture, hay and forage crops, or forests. An expansion of livestock and grass is taking place in other areas of the state, even though the pro cess may seem slow to some. John son says there are several plausible reasons why farm ers in eastern and southeastern Virginia have not fully embraced the cattle - pasture pro gram  A large p art of the cleared land is suitable for row-cropping, with less danger from surface erosion than in the m ountainous areas. It is hard to change immediately the viewpoint of a row-crop farm er who has fought grass as an arch enemy all his life. Fortunately, our educational efforts are succeeding in correcting this erroneous concept of grass, Johnson says. In those areas where cattle pro duction is in the process of develop m ent, some farm ers may be delay-. ing conversion because of their un-

document.text: You knew I was here, repeated Mr. Grimm musingly. And may I? Just as yon knew that I, or some one, at least, had entered this house a few minutes ago, she interrupted. The automobile horn outside was a signal, wasnt It? Hastings was In the car? Or was It Blair or Johnson? Mr. Grimm did not say. Didnt you anticipate any person al danger when you j entered ? he queried Instead. Werent you afraid I might shoot? No. There was a long silence. Mr. Grimm still sat with his elbows on his knees, staring at the vague white spotch which was Miss Thornes face and bare neck. One of her white arms hung at her side like a pallid serpent, and her hand was at rest on the seat of the couch. It seems, Miss Thorne, he said at length casually, that our paths of duty are inextricably tangled. Twice previously we have met under cir cumstances that were more than strange, and nowthis! Whatever In justice I may have done you In the past by my suspicions has, I hope, been forgiven and In each instance we were able to w6rk side by side to ward a conclusion. I am wondering now if this singular affair will take a similar course. He paused. Miss Thorne started to speak, but he silenced her with a Blight gesture of his hand. It is only fair to you to say that wethat Is, the Secret Servicehave learned many things about you, he resumed in the same casual tone. We have, through our foreign agents, traced you step by step from Rome to Washington. We know that you are, in a way, a representative of a sovereign of Europe we know that you were on a secret mission to the Spanish court, perhaps for this sover eign, and remained in Madrid for a month we know that from there you went to Paris, also on a secret mis sion-perhaps the sameand re mained there for three weeks we know that you met diplomatic agents of those governments later In London. We know all this we know the man ner of your coming to this country of your coming to Washington. But we dont know why you are here. Again she started to speak, and again he stopped her. We dont know your name, but that is of no consequence. We do know that In Spain you were Señora Cas- savant. In Paris Mademoiselle dAubl- non, in Londop Miss Jane Kellogg, and here Miss Isabel Thorne. We re alize that exigencies arise In your call ing, and mine, which make changes of name desirable, necessary even, and there is no criticism of that. Now as the representative of your govern mentrather a governmentyou have a right to be here, although unaccred ited you have a right to remain here as long as your acts are consistent with our laws you have a right to your secrets as long as they do not, directly 01 Indirectly, threaten the welfare of Oils country. Now, why are you here? He received no answer he expected none. After a moment he went on Admitting that you are a secret agent of Italy, admitting everything that you claim to be, you havent con vinced me that you are not the person who came here for the letters and cigarettes. You have said nothing to prove to my satisfaction that you are not the individual I was waiting for to-

document.text: Work was commenced on the big business and tenement block whioh Hr. D. 8. Jones some time ago arranged to build at the cor ner Of Twenty-eighth street and Lafayette avenue, Newport News. The block wUl be four stories high and have room enough on the first floor to acoomihodate several large stores. It is to be of briek. S, T. Bray, aged tblrty-slx yean, was found dead In bis bouse In Danville. The body was suspended by a rope from the top of a door frame, and from its condition the act must have been committed early tn the week. No one bos been staying in the house with Mr. Bray recently. On July 20 last Bray carried his wife and child to her fathers, at Christie, Va., and returned to Danville In a despondent mood. On August 27 he sold his interest in the Carter Maoblne Company to his partner, and stnee then had made several efforts to buy an Interest in established bouses here but without suocess. For several months past Bray had aoted strangely, and there is not much doubt but that constant brooding on some trouble, which he did not disclose, had affected his mind. Walter Witt, a brakeman on the Virginia Midland Division of the Southern Railway, was instantly killed at Staunton river bridge. Witt was passing over the cars on a freight train and his bead was struck by one of the beams of the bridge structure. The body was taken to Danville where Witt resided. The young brakeman had been marrlod only two weeks. Senator Faulkner Is reoeivlng the congrat ulations of his friends over the arrival of hie flrst grandchild, a son to Mr. and Mrs. Carter, In Wyoming. Mrs. Ruth Witt, of Handley, died Friday, Aged about ninety years. Mr. Oabriel Johnson died, after a protrac ted illness, at his home, near Cliff Mills, Fauquier county, in the eightieth year of his age. The ease of W. W. George against the Mathleson Alkali Works of Saltollle, Va., for alleged damages in the sum of 20,000, was decided In the Circuit Cqurt of Smythe County against the plaintiff. Mr. Oeorge was seriously injured in an accident at the alkali works a year ago. He also has a suit pending against the Norfolk aad Western Railway for alleged damages. The farmers of Caroline are still shipping portions of their last years crop of tobacco and are obtaining good prtceB. This county Is especially adapted to the raising of fine grades of tobacco, whioh command the high est prices. Judge H. M. Ford has returned to Lynch burg from Richmond and Norfolk, where he secured a pardon for W. E. Turner, former ly of the Norfolk and Western Railroad, who has been in the penitentiary for three years. It seems that Turner was the victim of a conspiracy of his wife, who accused him of an assault on her daughter, for which he was sentenced In the Corporation Court of Norfolk to ten years in the penitentiary. After the trial his wife secured a divorce and married an Englishman. Affidavits were made showing that her people admitted that It was a job put up on Turner by his wife, and it was on the strength of these that he was pardoned. The barn and contents, embracing farm ing Implements and about 600 bushels of wheat, on what is known as the Cassidy farm, near Waterford, now owned by Mrs. H. O. Gross, was ttoally destroyed by fire. Mr. Roger Jones farms the place and had housed his wheat crop in the barn, which was a very large one. He was thrashing his wheat, the thrasher being in the barn and the engine just outside. A spark Ignaled the straw and everything went up In flames. The thrasher belongod to George Fry. On the 16th Instant the Hon. William Lynne Wilson will be formally Installed as President of Washington and Lee Univer sity. The exercises pill take place in the university chapel, beginning at 11 oclock. Addresses will be delivered by President Patton, of Princeton University, President Oilman, of Johoa Hopkins University, and Chanoellor Kirkland, of Vanderbilt Univer sity. Following this there will be an address of ao icptance by President Wilson. Then the oath of office will be administered to him by the university rector, Judge William Mo- Laugblin. At 2 oclock In the afternoon a banquet will be held in the university gym nasium. Many distinguished educators of the North and South will be present. Mrs. Ella M. Burkholder, wife of Dr. N. M. Burkholder, died suddenly of heart fail ure on August 29 at their residence Fort Lynne, near Harrisonburg. Mrs. Burk holder was a daughter of Dr. Beuben Moore and a granddaughter of the late Samuel Cootes, of Rockingham. Mr. Chas. B. Wood, the pioneer fruit grower of Rappahannock county, was offer ed last week by John J. Miller, 5,000 for his apple crop, which offer he refused. The trees In h!s orchard, which is the finest in that section, are loaded down with the finest fruit, being unusally large and per fect.

document.text: Work has begun on th e . general reassessment of real estate being conducted in Buckingham County. A Board of Assesors has been appointed by the Circuit Court consisting of the following members Dr. Edgar Johnson, Chairman Gordon Ragland, Sr., Secre tary C. L. Hardiman Percy Gregory and R. S. Ellis, III. The reassessment conducted by the Board will be effective for 1982 real estate taxes. The general reassessment was called for by the Buckingham County Board of Supervisors, The last .general reassessment was conducted in 1976. Virginia Law requires reassessments to be con ducted every four years, but a reassessment may be delayed one or two years if desired by the Board of Supervisors. For the present cycle, the Board of Supervisors chose a five-year interval. State Law requires real estate to be assessed at its fair market value.  The Board of Supervisors decision to conduct a reassessment now was in fluenced by a State Depart ment of Taxation study. That study showed , the average real estate parcel was assessd at 78 of its estimated fair market value as of 1978. The study also indicated Some disparitylBWWeen the assessment or various Cate gories of real estate. During times of high inflation, it is expected that rapid changes in land values would increase the difference bet ween the assessed value and the actual fair market value. The Board of Supervisors has hired appraisers to assist the Board of Asses sors with the reassessment. The appraiser will visit every parcel in the County, make an initial estimate of its value, and present that information to the Board of Assessors foi its review. Three members of the Board of. assessors will meet with the appraisers on an . average of one day per week to review the appraisers work. The appraisers employed

document.text: Women still think of clothes as tops on the important list. I. Byrd Johnson, clothing special ist at VPI, reports that in 1953 consumer expendtiures on clothing were more than three times that of the average for the 30s. But during the same period, clothing expenses took a lower per centage of the total income. This doesnt mean the textile and manu facturing business will stop, .there are more people to clothe, she says. The mens-wear market includ ing H5 years of age and over will increase by 15,000,000 by 1970. The womens-wear market 15 years or over is growing slightly faster than the mens market. The total increase is expected to be 18,000,- 000 by 1970. The market for the age group over 40 is expected to in crease somewhat faster than that for younger people. In Virginia, Miss Johnson says, the 1953 figures available indicate taht 9 to 10 of the spendable income was used on clothing the family. The middle of the road or median family con sisted of four members and spent 3175.97. This amount of money was seldom divided evenly among the members, but acording to then needsbased on activities and on growth. In 1954 the average price for wearing apparel has risen slightly, about 1 higher than a year ago. A few declines in prices of womens clothing are noted, restricted to items made of man-made fiber. Prices of cotton apparel and of mens and childrens shoes have in creased a little.

document.text: Wives and sweethearts of Ameri can soldiers in the South Pacific j neednt worry about competition from native girls of the islands, par- i ticularly the Solon ions, according to Osa Johnson. Mrs. Jonnson, familiar with many wild and remote lands, knows a lot about the Solomons. Shortly after her marriage to the late Martin Johnson, her husband I talked her into going to those islands  and her life there she describes with , much vividness in her latest book,   Bride in the Solomons. Houghton Miflin But getting back to the is land ladies. They are absolutely without lure, Mrs. Johnson declared as we chatted in her pleasant Park avenue offices. Judging by almost i any standard, they are entirely de-  ficient in pulchritude. Also they bathe so seldom that a young girl going around barefooted, which i they all do, looks as if she were j wearing puttees.    In the Solomons, Mrs. Johnson  continued, a woman has the value of a pigandthe pigs run wild. If some young man desires a damsel for his bride, he gives the chief a pig. The chief in turn presents the pig to the family of the bride-to-be. The family in turn provides a feast at which the pig is eaten. If the bridegroom wishes another bride, he gets hold of another pig. Sometimes the brides family gets a little up pity and demands cash in addition to the pig. That isnt hard since cash consists of shells and porpoise teeth. Speaking of pigs, Mrs. John son told me that they, as well as dogs, were introduced in the islands by Captain Cook. Boars break off their front teeth. The new one comes in curved and the more times it is broken off, the more it curls until sometimes there is . a beautiful double curvé.    Even young women in the Solo mons look old, Mrs. Johnson said. That isnt due entirely to the fact that there are no beauty parlors and nose-bobbing and face-lifting are unknown. Its  mostly because the women do all the work. The lord and master may condescend to lay out a garden, but it is the women of his household who do thé plant ing and the harvesting. Also they do the cooking, baking, the hut building and other little chores. So  low is the estate of woman that a j mother isnt allowed to raise her  own son. The men have a big club- , house where women are not per mitted to enter. At an early age, I the son is taken to the clubhouse where he is taught to be a warrior. If his mother wants to see him, she ! must stand at a respectful distance 1 and call to him.   Tabuism applied even to Mrs. I Johnson. She was wild to look into I one of the head houses  the I plate where such trophies as human heads are stored. But she never got the chance. Or rather she didnt take the chance of indulging in so much as a peek. To have done so would have caused trouble  much trouble. In the first place, she j would have been killed. In the sec- i ond place, her husband would j have been killed. Then having made the start? the natives would keep right on until all white men within reach and probably a lot of natives were slain. Thus, vengeanceand a meat supply. Cannabalism, despite all attempts to stamp it out, still exists Mrs. Johnson averred. When things get too hot along the coast, the head hunters merely move to the mountains.    Mrs. Johnson, a native of Chanute, Kan., in her own words, was merely a  little country girl, when her husband induced her to go to the Solomons by picturing the ! islands as an earthly paradise, with I beautiful flowers, languid climate, I etc. She found the flowers all right I but many were poisonous. She also I found rats as big as rabbits, huge spiders and landcrabs that would nip off fingers. Along with snakes, humidity, torrential rains and jungle stink that cannot be de scribed. But Martin Johnson got what he went aftermotion pictures of head hunters. He made the mov ies and his wife made the stills, many of which are reproduced in j  Bride in the Solomons. Also Mrs.  Johnson became so proficient with  a rifle she shot dov.n cocoanuts.

document.text: With last weeks balmy weather, sportsmens thoughts turned to spring -athletics, and the Appomattox varsity base ball team began practice in preparation for its first-game, March 18. Coach Howard Clabotigh says that 27 athletes havecome out for baseball practice this year. There are eight returning players from. 1980s team , including four starters, accord ing to Clabough. R eturnees include Kenny Wayne Burks catcher, out field, who batted .400 last year and led the team in runs batted in Neal Cole, who hit .288 last year and played outfield Bucky Totty outfield, who hit .324 last year Keith Mann, a good glove man who played short stop last year Marvin Johnson pjteher, first base Ricky Harris outfield Steve Poole outfield and. Kevin Mitchell, a pitcher who played on the varsity team last yelr as a freshman. Clabough says there are 11 players from last years junior varsity squad who are trying out for varsity this year. , A lot of those sophomores are going to push the older players for their jobs this year, according to Clabbugh. We have some very talented sophomores coming up. .W e lost six seniors ,last year, according to Clabough, including our best pitcher Darrell Schrock and two of our better hitters SteveCobb and Terry Woods. Clabough says his squad will work on improving on last years 9-11 record. We were a little weak in pitching last year, notes the coach. We have some sophomore pitchers who were hoping are going to help us out in that department this year Greg Mayberry, Tim Benuett-and Kevin Mitchell.  The varsity squad will play only 16 games this year, as compared with 20 last year, according to Clabough. AU the teem s were cut back to conserve energy, explains the coach.  Eight of those 16 games will be at home, and there will be a scrimmage against Heritage within the next two weeks, but the time hasnt been establish ed yet. The season opener March 18.. will be against E.C. Glass at E. C. Glass.

document.text: With eight starters out, they played toe-to-toe withn the number-six ranked team in the state. In the opinion of the coaches, we physically out-hit a much larger team, Cuccio noted. Cuccio added that for the way in which theyve overcome adversity and played their hearts out, I personally am prouder of this team than any other since Ive been at Appomattox. We hope we can continue the inten sity of our play for the next two weeks, the coach said. Quarterback Paul Johnson, back full speed after an injury sustained in the Buckingham game, completed five of 13 passes for 53 yards. Ricky Turner was the Raiders leading rusher, carrying the ball nine times for 50 yards. Steve Hamlett ran the ball three times for 16 yards for Appomattox. This Friday night, the Raiders will This Friday night, the Raiders will face off against Altavista for the final home game of the 1963 football season. Altavista has a much-improved football team, Cuccio said this week. They beat Liberty and Jefferson Forest, and we feel they are a good team. But we believed our boys will be ready to play. _ - The game gets underway Friday night at 8 p.m at Bragg Stadium, behind Appomattox Middle School off Route 460.

document.text: with 25 points, Ferguson with. 21, Marvin Johnson with 12, mid Rick Caldwell with 11 points. The Raiders jumped into an early lead in the first quarter, which ended with the local team ahead, 20-12. In the second quarter, the Raiders continued their domination iff the game, scoring 20 points to Libertys 11, and the score at the end of the first half stood at 40-23, favor of Appomattox. The Raiders exploded for 25 mqre points  in the third quart, while holding Liberty to 15 points. In the final period of play, the Raiders garnered , 21 moré points, held Liberty to 17 points, and wop the game by 31 points, 86-55. With the Raiders scoring in double figures for the game were Je ff Miller with six points, Ron Carter with five points, Normán Turner with three points, and Jody Williams with three. Shane Abernathy pulled in 17 rebounds for the. Raiders, and the team hit 32 field goals and went 22 for 29 from the foul line for a 75 percent freethrow performance. The Raiders were scheduled to complete their regular season Tuesday night at home against Rustburg, after the Ibues-Virginian deadline. The Raiders have clinched a spot in the Seminole District tourna ment, to be held starting Feb. 24 at E . C. Glass High School in Lynchburg. As of press time, however, the team with which the Raiders would be paired in the opening  round of the tourney had yet to te determined.
